baby: Brain and spinal cord are rapidly forming; facial features begin to take shape.
Heart is beating and circulating blood through tiny vessels.
Limb buds look like paddles; early cartilage is forming for future bones.
Neural tube has closed; early eye and inner ear structures are developing.
nicole: Hormones (hCG, progesterone, estrogen) are high—fatigue, nausea, and breast tenderness are common.
Blood volume and heart rate begin rising; lightheadedness can occur, especially when standing quickly.
Uterus is growing but still in the pelvis; cramping can be normal, but severe pain should be evaluated.
Smell sensitivity and food aversions may peak; hydration becomes a daily priority.
jake: Own the logistics: schedule/confirm appointments, manage meds/supplements list, and track questions for the OB/REI.
Build the ‘no-judgment’ food plan: keep safe snacks, bland options, and hydration aids (electrolytes, ginger tea).
Protect rest: take over physically demanding chores; create a calm bedtime routine and low-stimulus evenings.
Validate symptoms without problem-solving first; ask ‘Do you want comfort, solutions, or space?’
todos: If not already done: early prenatal visit/ultrasound, confirm dating, review meds and supplements.
Start a simple tracking habit: symptoms, hydration, and any spotting/cramps to discuss with provider.
nutrition: Aim for a prenatal vitamin with folic acid; confirm any extra supplements with the provider (especially iron, DHA, vitamin D).
Hydration target: frequent sips all day; add electrolytes if nausea/vomiting is present.
Food safety basics: avoid unpasteurized dairy, high-mercury fish, and undercooked meats/eggs; reheat deli meats if advised by provider.
Focus on ‘survival nutrition’: small frequent meals, protein + carbs, and whatever stays down; nausea management is a health priority.
Gentle movement (short walks, stretching) can help energy and constipation—only as tolerated.
redflags: Heavy bleeding (soaking a pad), passing large clots, or severe one-sided pelvic pain
Fever ≥ 100.4°F (38°C), severe dehydration, or inability to keep fluids down
Severe headache, vision changes, chest pain, or shortness of breath at rest
Sudden significant swelling of face/hands, or right upper abdominal pain
Leakage of fluid you suspect could be amniotic fluid
After ~24 weeks: decreased fetal movement vs Nicole’s normal pattern
Any concern that ‘something isn’t right’—trust the instinct and call the care team

Hands and feet start to show distinct fingers/toes (still webbed).
Eyelids are forming; ears are moving toward their final position.
Tail-like structure disappears as the body straightens and lengthens.

baby: Neck strengthens; head becomes more proportional to the body.
Facial expressions are possible as muscles develop.
Liver and spleen contribute to blood production; skin is very thin/transparent.
Lanugo (fine hair) begins to appear in coming weeks.
nicole: Energy often improves; nausea may lessen, though not for everyone.
Uterus rises into the abdomen—belly growth becomes more noticeable.
Ligaments stretch (round ligament pain) causing sharp twinges with movement.
Skin and circulation changes can show up (glow, nasal congestion, mild swelling).
jake: Help Nicole stay comfortable: support pillows, gentle walks, and proactive breaks during errands/outings.
Be the health advocate: attend key visits, take notes, and understand screening/ultrasound results.
Start nesting as a project: research baby gear, set up registry, and handle big purchases and returns.
Keep connection: weekly ‘check-in’ (10–15 min) on feelings, needs, and what’s working.
todos: Second trimester planning: ask when anatomy scan will be scheduled (often 18–22 weeks).
symptoms: Round ligament pain, mild back/hip discomfort
Skin changes (stretch marks, linea nigra, pigmentation)
nutrition: Aim for a prenatal vitamin with folic acid; confirm any extra supplements with the provider (especially iron, DHA, vitamin D).
Hydration target: frequent sips all day; add electrolytes if nausea/vomiting is present.
Food safety basics: avoid unpasteurized dairy, high-mercury fish, and undercooked meats/eggs; reheat deli meats if advised by provider.
Prioritize protein, fiber, and calcium; add iron-rich foods and pair with vitamin C to improve absorption.
Add pelvic-friendly strength: glute/hip work, posture, and core stability (often with prenatal PT guidance).

Food safety basics: avoid unpasteurized dairy, high-mercury fish, and undercooked meats/eggs; reheat deli meats if advised by provider.
Prioritize protein, fiber, and calcium; add iron-rich foods and pair with vitamin C to improve absorption.
Add pelvic-friendly strength: glute/hip work, posture, and core stability (often with prenatal PT guidance).
redflags: Heavy bleeding (soaking a pad), passing large clots, or severe one-sided pelvic pain
Fever ≥ 100.4°F (38°C), severe dehydration, or inability to keep fluids down
Severe headache, vision changes, chest pain, or shortness of breath at rest
Sudden significant swelling of face/hands, or right upper abdominal pain
Leakage of fluid you suspect could be amniotic fluid
After ~24 weeks: decreased fetal movement vs Nicole’s normal pattern
Any concern that ‘something isn’t right’—trust the instinct and call the care team

baby: Digestive system practices by swallowing; taste may be influenced by amniotic fluid.
Bone marrow begins making blood cells, reducing reliance on liver/spleen.
Eyelids and eyebrows are well formed; more facial features are defined.
Movements are stronger and more coordinated.
nicole: Energy often improves; nausea may lessen, though not for everyone.
Uterus rises into the abdomen—belly growth becomes more noticeable.
Ligaments stretch (round ligament pain) causing sharp twinges with movement.
Skin and circulation changes can show up (glow, nasal congestion, mild swelling).
Back/hip discomfort can increase as posture shifts; core and pelvic stability become important.
jake: Help Nicole stay comfortable: support pillows, gentle walks, and proactive breaks during errands/outings.

baby: Third trimester begins: rapid weight gain and brain growth.
Eyes can open/close; eyelashes are present.
Lungs are still maturing; surfactant increases significantly in coming weeks.
Baby’s movements may feel stronger and more defined (rolls, stretches).
nicole: Breathlessness and heartburn can increase as the uterus crowds the diaphragm and stomach.
Sleep can be harder due to frequent urination, discomfort, and active baby movements.
Swelling in feet/ankles can be common; sudden or severe swelling should be reported.
Braxton Hicks contractions may become more frequent—usually irregular and improve with rest/hydration.
jake: Run interference: limit overcommitments, protect sleep, and handle late-pregnancy house tasks.
Practice ‘labor support reps’: breathing cues, counter-pressure, position changes, and timing contractions.
Finalize the plan: hospital bag, car seat install, pediatrician, leave/coverage, and postpartum help.
Watch for red flags too: severe headache, vision changes, heavy bleeding, decreased fetal movement—call promptly.
Mark the milestone: plan a low-key celebration (photo, note to Eila, or a simple date).
todos: Glucose screening for gestational diabetes is often done between 24–28 weeks; clarify prep instructions.
Ask about Rhogam timing if Nicole is Rh-negative (often around 28 weeks).
Third-trimester logistics: confirm childcare/pet plan, leave paperwork, and preferred hospital/birth center procedures.
Consider a childbirth/breastfeeding/infant care class (in-person or online).
symptoms: Shortness of breath with exertion, heartburn
Swelling of feet/ankles; carpal tunnel symptoms
nutrition: Aim for a prenatal vitamin with folic acid; confirm any extra supplements with the provider (especially iron, DHA, vitamin D).
Hydration target: frequent sips all day; add electrolytes if nausea/vomiting is present.
Food safety basics: avoid unpasteurized dairy, high-mercury fish, and undercooked meats/eggs; reheat deli meats if advised by provider.
Smaller meals can reduce reflux; avoid lying down right after eating; consider left-side rest for circulation comfort.
Daily movement plus mobility can reduce swelling and improve sleep; stop if dizziness, bleeding, fluid leakage, or pain occurs.
